evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication, delayed responses, and coordination lapses.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight data recorded on 12-25 under hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal is robust against common defeaters, ensuring reliable detection despite potential data noise or confounding factors.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal dataset, reflecting relevant operational parameters and deviations.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal dataset.

assumptions: The absence of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate communication breakdown rather than procedural deviation.
The headset operator and wingman roles imply responsibility for communication and alerting.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordinated actions preventing the incident, or if the incident was caused by procedural deviation without communication failure.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during the pushback, supporting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about whether procedural deviations or communication failures were primary cause; evidence does not fully exclude alternative root causes.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight data recorded on 12-25 under hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.

assumptions: The recorded flight data and history accurately reflect the pushback event
No mechanical faults were present as no evidence indicates such
Environmental markings were adequate as per H7 and H13
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical failure or equipment fault causing the pushback deviation
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible, supporting R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY
If communication logs or witness statements indicated coordination failure rather than procedural deviation

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the procedural deviation with the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast barrier. H8 and H12 provide context on communication and control during pushback, supporting that the deviation was procedural rather than due to communication breakdown or environmental factors.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in communication effectiveness and operator awareness; no direct mechanical fault evidence

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication, delayed responses, and coordination lapses.

assumptions: Miscommunication and lack of warnings among crew constitute communication/coordination breakdown.
Delayed responses and coordination lapses are inferred from crew not intervening or warning despite awareness.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordinated responses preventing the incident, or if mechanical failure was primary cause.
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the main factor.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 describe miscommunication and lack of timely warnings among crew members during pushback, consistent with communication/coordination breakdown key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or communication breakdown was primary cause; limited explicit statements on coordination lapses.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal dataset, reflecting relevant operational parameters and deviations.

assumptions: The TRP markings and environment were adequate and visible as per H7 and related context.
Crew qualifications and training were sufficient to recognize and act upon TRP limits.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, or that environmental factors prevented proper stopping at the TRP, this would favor environmental deficiency over procedural deviation.
If equipment malfunction or control failure was documented causing the pushback beyond the TRP, this would challenge the procedural deviation claim.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, and H12 directly describe the procedural deviation in pushback execution, showing the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite operational parameters and crew actions, supporting alignment with key features of procedural deviation rather than environmental or marking deficiencies.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in the adequacy and visibility of TRP markings and communication effectiveness among crew members.

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal is robust against common defeaters, ensuring reliable detection despite potential data noise or confounding factors.

assumptions: The tug instructor's statements accurately reflect the procedural context
No undisclosed mechanical faults influenced the pushback beyond procedural deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical control failure or environmental factors caused the deviation rather than procedural errors
If communication breakdowns or environmental deficiencies were proven to be primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 directly support that procedural deviation identification is robust against common defeaters such as communication lapses or operator distraction, as the instructor's actions and lack of warnings indicate reliable detection despite potential confounding factors.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in interpreting operator actions and communication effectiveness

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal data.

assumptions: The crew had adequate knowledge of TRP markings and procedures as indicated by training references.
No mechanical or environmental factors interfered with the pushback operation beyond communication issues.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were unclear or not visible to the crew, or that mechanical failures prevented stopping, this would challenge the communication breakdown explanation.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows that communication signals and warnings were absent or unheeded, supporting that communication/coordination breakdown explains the event and alternative causes like marking deficiencies are less likely.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew perception and possible unreported environmental factors
